title: Jannah (Syurga) — Thematic Facts (al-Quran, Sahih Hadis, Classical Tafsir)
generated_by: GPT (compiled from al-Quran, Sahih Hadis, Ibn Kathir, Al-Qurtubi, Al-Tabari, Ibn Hajar, Al-Nawawi)
notes: Each fact uses only al-Quran, sahih/hasan Hadis, or classical Tafsir. 'authenticity' indicates primary source Kekuatan. 'interpretation' flags whether scholars treat it literally or with caution.

themes.title: Physical Environment
themes.summary: Gardens, rivers, trees, palaces and the general landscape of Syurga.

facts.fact: Gardens (jannat) with rivers flowing Di bawah them are a primary descriptor of Syurga.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir explains 'gardens Di bawah which rivers Mengalir' as a recurring Qur'anic Imej of Jannah's enduring bounty.

facts.fact: There are rivers of Air, Susu, Madu, and Suci Arak in Syurga.
facts.scholar_note: Classical Tafsir (Ibn Kathir) treats the four rivers as literal blessings, emphasizing purity and difference from worldly analogues.

facts.fact: Palaces, lofty dwellings, and tents—some described as hollowed pearls—are among the abodes.
facts.reference: Sahih al-Bukhari; Sahih Muslim (hadith about dwellings); Tafsir Ibn Kathir
facts.scholar_note: Hadis Literatur (Bukhari/Muslim) mentions tents and homes made of pearls; scholars generally Menerima these narrations as describing real rewards.

facts.fact: A special Pokok exists whose shade stretches a journey of a hundred years.
facts.scholar_note: Found in Bukhari and Muslim; scholars Membawa its enormous size as literal

facts.fact: The width and scope of Syurga are vast — described as comparable to the heavens and the earth in Mengganjar and extent.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir emphasizes the vastness to convey scale rather than precise cosmological measurements.

facts.fact: Rivers Mengalir Di bawah palaces and gardens; inhabitants often recline on raised couches overlooking flowing Air.
facts.scholar_note: Many verses pair couches/sofas with rivers to depict restful luxury.

themes.title: Inhabitants & Companions
themes.summary: Who lives in Syurga, their appearance, and companions (including hur al-’ayn).

facts.fact: Believers of varying ranks will dwell there—Prophets, martyrs, the righteous—and one’s rank corresponds to deeds.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir and others emphasize gradation according to deeds and stations.

facts.fact: Inhabitants will be youthful, often described as around the age of thirty-three (appearance of perpetual youth).
facts.reference: Sunan al-Tirmidhi 2545; Sahih Muslim narrations on appearance
facts.scholar_note: Hadis Menerangkan youthful appearance; scholars Negara this indicates perpetual Tenaga.

facts.fact: Hur al-’ayn (Suci companions) are described in the Qur’an and Hadis as Suci and reserved for Syurga.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir explains hur al-’ayn as Suci companions; detail beyond the Qur’an is primarily from Hadis and scholarly explanation.

facts.fact: Rakyat in Syurga will be with their righteous Keluarga members if they wished (reunion is promised for those who are righteous).
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir notes conditional reunification for those united by Iman and righteousness.

facts.fact: The lowest person in Syurga will have a Berkongsi vastly superior to the whole worldly life—Hadis mention multiplicative rewards.
facts.scholar_note: Hadis emphasize scale and abundance compared to worldly wealth.

facts.fact: Rakyat will be served by youthful attendants described in Qur’an imagery as 'like scattered pearls'.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir interprets 'scattered pearls' as imagery for the beauty and Memerintah of servants; cautions about over-literalizing social roles.

themes.title: Pakaian, Jewelry & Furnishings
themes.summary: Garments, jewelry, thrones, and seating described for Jannah's dwellers.

facts.fact: Dwellers will wear garments of fine silk and brocade.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir notes silk and brocade symbolize enduring and elevated adornment.

facts.fact: They will wear bracelets of gold and pearls.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir explains these ornaments signify Menghormati and beauty, not material ostentation.

facts.fact: Raised couches and thrones (mahali) are repeatedly mentioned as places of repose and company.
facts.scholar_note: Thrones and couches denote comfort and status; Bukhari/Muslim Memasukkan Hadis about reclining in rows.

facts.fact: There are vessels of gold and cups passed among inhabitants.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir explains golden vessels as symbols of perpetual provision.

facts.fact: Tents made from hollowed pearls are narrated in sahih Hadis as individual abodes.
facts.scholar_note: Hadis mentions huge pearls as tents; scholars Menerima as descriptions of Mengganjar.

facts.fact: Decor and furnishings will be of precious materials—gold, silver, pearls—indicating permanence and Menghormati.
facts.scholar_note: Classical Tafsir views precious materials as expressions of Kekal Menghormati.

themes.title: Makanan & Minuman
themes.summary: Fruits, meats, drinks, and the nature of sustenance in Syurga.

facts.fact: Fruits of Syurga hang within easy reach and are of unending variety and ease of access.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir stresses ease and abundance, contrasting worldly Bersusah for Buah-buahan.

facts.fact: Rakyat will be served Daging and fruits as they desire—completely satisfying and without digestive need.
facts.scholar_note: Hadis clarifies that inhabitants will eat without the worldly consequences (no excretion).

facts.fact: There is sealed, Suci nectar (kafur/nectar) which does not intoxicate or cause Penyakit.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir: this Minuman is unlike worldly Arak—Suci and restful.

facts.fact: No bodily impurity (urine, stool, mucus) will occur in Syurga, despite eating and drinking.
facts.scholar_note: Hadis explicitly contrasts worldly needs and Jannah's purity.

facts.fact: Fruits will be different from worldly fruits—Suci, easy to pluck, and perpetually fresh.
facts.scholar_note: Scholars underscore qualitative difference from that which we Tahu.

facts.fact: Makanan and Minuman will be served in abundance without Usaha or negative aftereffects.
facts.scholar_note: Hadis and al-Quran pair to Menunjukkan effortless provision.

themes.title: Social Life & Activities
themes.summary: Markets, greetings, meetings, and communal life in Syurga.

facts.fact: There is a weekly gathering/market in Syurga (some narrations say every Friday) where Rakyat meet and revisit the worldly life as memories.
facts.scholar_note: Hadis describes a market-like meeting used for Kegembiraan and exchange of blessings.

facts.fact: Rakyat will greet each other with Kedamaian (salam) and will be Membebaskan of Iri or hatred.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir highlights the social perfection—unbroken bonds and Suci relations.

facts.fact: Residents will remember the worldly life only as a brief thing (memories without Sakit), often as a moment or a glimpse.
facts.scholar_note: Scholars Menerangkan this to Menunjukkan Kekal perspective.

facts.fact: Rakyat will be seated in rows facing each other and will enjoy conversation, laughter, and scenes of Kegembiraan.
facts.scholar_note: Classical Tafsir links such verses to communal delight.

facts.fact: There will be no idle speech, backbiting, or harmful Bercakap—only words of Kedamaian and Memuji.
facts.scholar_note: Indicates moral purity of speech.

facts.fact: Angels Masuk through every Pintu gerbang to greet the inhabitants with Kedamaian and blessings.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir describes angelic felicitation as a Tanda of Menghormati.

themes.title: Rohani Joys & Seeing Allah
themes.summary: The Rohani and transcendent rewards, foremost being the vision of the Lord.

facts.fact: The greatest bliss of Syurga is the beatific vision — seeing Allah — affirmed in sahih Hadis.
facts.reference: Sahih al-Bukhari 7444; Sahih Muslim 181; Tafsir Ibn Kathir
facts.scholar_note: Classical consensus sees the vision of Allah as the highest Mengganjar; Tafsir Literatur discusses theological implications.

facts.fact: Residents will experience perfection of Jantung: no hatred, Iri, anxiety, or grief.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir explains Rohani purity as part of Kekal felicity.

facts.fact: The Rohani contentment in Syurga is permanent; Kegembiraan will not fade and will Meningkatkan.
facts.scholar_note: Scholars emphasize 'everlasting' aspects of Iluhi pleasure.

facts.fact: Glorification and remembrance of Allah will be effortless and natural—part of Syurga's delight.
facts.scholar_note: Hadis mentions dhikr as natural repose.

facts.fact: There will be no trials, sorrow, Sakit, or fatigue—Suci, uninterrupted ecstasy.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir contrasts Syurga's permanence with temporal worldly trials.

facts.fact: Blessings will Meningkatkan according to deeds and Iluhi generosity—Rohani ranks vary.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir and others Menjelaskan that rewards are both just and abundant.

themes.title: Ranks, Entry & Gates
themes.summary: Gates, highest levels (Al-Firdaws), admission criteria and ranks inside Syurga.

facts.fact: Syurga has Lapan gates, each Pintu gerbang associated with particular acts of Beribadah or groups mentioned in Hadis.
facts.scholar_note: Hadis narrations link gates to categories (e.g., prayer, charity), Tafsir expands on symbolism.

facts.fact: Al-Firdaws (al-firdaus) is described as the highest and central part of Syurga Di bawah the Takhta of Allah.
facts.scholar_note: Scholars stress the excellence and centrality of al-Firdaws.

facts.fact: Admission is by Allah's Rahmat and by Iman and righteous action; intercession (shafa'ah) is a promised Rahmat for some.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir and Hadis Berbincang limits and the role of Rahmat and intercession.

facts.fact: Ranks differ: Rakyat are placed according to deeds—Prophets, martyrs, sincere worshippers occupy higher stations.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir and Al-Qurtubi detail rank distinctions.

facts.fact: The first to Masuk Syurga will Memasukkan the prophets and the most righteous; the Prophet Muhammad ﷺ is described as among the first.
facts.scholar_note: Hadis corpus marks key figures entering early as honorific precedence.

facts.fact: Some believers who sinned may Masuk Neraka temporarily for purification and later be admitted to Syurga by Allah’s Rahmat (as per sahih narrations).
facts.scholar_note: Scholars Menerangkan this as part of Iluhi Keadilan and Rahmat—Muslims who Mati with major Dosa without repentance may be purified.

themes.title: Measurements & Extraordinary Dimensions
themes.summary: Narrated sizes, distances, and physical exaggerations used to convey majesty and scale.

facts.fact: Some Hadis Menerangkan enormous physical attributes (e.g., tents/homes measured in wide spans, huge Gigi, large distances) to denote scale.
facts.reference: Sahih al-Bukhari; Sahih Muslim; Tafsir Ibn Kathir
facts.scholar_note: Scholars Menerima narrated magnitudes but caution that some may be metaphorical for scale rather than literal engineering specs.

facts.fact: There are Hadis specifying enormous sizes for some Syurga features (e.g., a tent of a Orang beriman as a hollowed pearl many miles wide).
facts.scholar_note: Hadis are taken as authentic; Tafsir authors Berbincang whether to Menerima these literally or as indicative of immense Mengganjar.

facts.fact: Trees and shades are sometimes given journeys or time-measures (e.g., shade spanning a hundred years) to communicate immensity.
facts.scholar_note: Scholars generally Menerima the Hadis; Berdebat focuses on whether 'hundred years' is literal distance/time or hyperbolic to convey vastness.

facts.fact: The rewards of the lowest person in Syurga are said to surpass the entire world many times over (Hadiths express this multiplicative Idea).
facts.scholar_note: This shows qualitative, not only quantitative, superiority.

facts.fact: Descriptions sometimes use travel-time metaphors to express size (e.g., 'a Pokok whose shade a traveler would cross in many years').
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir notes rhetorical use to convey grandeur.

facts.fact: Tafsir Literatur often reframes extraordinary measurements as signs of unimaginable Mengganjar rather than physical blueprints.
facts.scholar_note: Scholars stress that human concepts of measure are inadequate to Menangkap Kekal realities.

themes.title: Emotional Negara & Purity
themes.summary: No sorrow, no fatigue, absence of impurity and perfect contentment.

facts.fact: There will be no grief, Takut, anxiety, or sadness in Syurga.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir: Selesai emotional perfection and Kedamaian are central attributes.

facts.fact: Inhabitants will not Menderita any Penyakit, aging, or Kematian—perpetual Kesihatan and youthfulness are promised.
facts.scholar_note: Hadis includes explicit statements about absence of Penyakit, aging, and Kematian.

facts.fact: There will be no bodily impurities (no urine, stool, mucus), yet pleasures of eating/drinking will Kekal.
facts.scholar_note: A strong Hadis stressing the qualitative difference of bodily functioning in Syurga.

facts.fact: Scent in Syurga is Suci; inhabitants sweat a fragrance like musk instead of foul perspiration.
facts.scholar_note: Described in Hadis as musk-scented sweat—indicates refined bodily Negara.

facts.fact: Hearts will be united—no Iri, hatred or broken ties; Rakyat will be content and loving.
facts.scholar_note: Hadis and al-Quran together depict moral perfection among inhabitants.

facts.fact: Kegembiraan and laughter are described as part of social felicity—memories of hardship become trivial.
facts.scholar_note: Scholars emphasize remedial aspect—worldly pains become insignificant.

themes.title: Warnings, Causes & Access
themes.summary: What leads to Jannah, warnings, Rahmat, and the relation of deeds/Rahmat to entry.

facts.fact: Entry to Syurga is by Allah’s Rahmat; righteous deeds and Iman are the means, but ultimately acceptance is by Iluhi Rahmat.
facts.reference: Qur'an 4:123; Sahih Hadith on mercy and deeds
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir Literatur repeatedly stresses the balance of Iluhi Keadilan and Rahmat.

facts.fact: Kepercayaan (iman) and righteous action (amal salih) are repeatedly given as the cause for Syurga.
facts.scholar_note: Tafsir: practical examples Memasukkan prayer, fasting, charity.

facts.fact: Warnings and admonitions in Qur’an and Hadis Menunjukkan that sinful behavior, ingratitude, and hypocrisy imperil admission.
facts.scholar_note: Ibn Kathir and others compile lists of culpable acts; scholars emphasize repentance.

facts.fact: Intercession (shafa'ah) is a promised Rahmat; the Prophet ﷺ and others will intercede by Allah’s permission.
facts.reference: Sahih al-Bukhari; Sahih Muslim (hadith on shafa'ah)
facts.scholar_note: Major theological works Berbincang limits and conditions of intercession.

facts.fact: Consistent small righteous deeds are emphasized (Hadis about small acts accumulating rewards leading to Syurga).
facts.scholar_note: Hadiths encourage steady practice; scholars emphasize sustainability of Beribadah.

facts.fact: Syurga is described as surrounded by hardships—the Laluan to it entails Bergelut, trials, and moral vigilance.
facts.reference: Sahih al-Bukhari 6487; Qur'an passages on trials
facts.scholar_note: Hadis metaphorically and literally describes hardships that refine believers.
